awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Flood volcanism and environmental impacts -- A multidisciplinary investigation of the Deccan Traps and events at the Cretaceous-Paleogene boundary
awd_abstract_narration:
Increasing evidence suggests that the four most recent mass extinction events: end-Guadalupian; end-Permian; Triassic-Jurassic boundary; Cretaceous-Paleogene boundary (KPB)- are closely associated in time with continental flood basalt (CFB) volcanism. Paradoxically, the KPB is associated with both the Deccan Traps CFB and the Chicxulub impact in Yucatan, Mexico, engendering an intense three-decades-old debate over causal relationships. Deccan volcanism began well before and continued well after KPB/Chicxulub time, but the largest Deccan eruptions (Wai Sub-group) appear to have been initiated within ~50,000 years of both the KPB and the Chicxulub impact, suggesting that this subset of eruptions may have been triggered by the impact. It remains unclear whether large Deccan flood basalt eruptions or the Chicxulub impact (or both) were the cause of the KPB extinction, because both may have injected massive amounts of volatiles, aerosols, and particulates into the atmosphere. This project's research will improve our understanding of the genesis, timing, and environmental effects of Deccan Traps volcanism by considering Earth systems interactions from mantle plume convection to crustal magmatism to eruption and to atmosphere/biosphere effects. 

The research will include studies of: (1) The genesis and geodynamic context of Deccan magmatism based on physical volcanology and geochemical signatures, coupled with analysis of volatile contents; (2) Radioisotopic geochronology of the Deccan Traps to tightly constrain their eruptive tempo and relation to other KPB events; (3) Geophysical modeling of mantle and crustal magmatic processes, launching of volatiles and aerosols by the Deccan eruptions, and mechanisms of volcanic triggering by dynamic (seismic) stresses due to earthquakes and impacts; (4) Analysis of geophysical exploration data from offshore western India that has not previously been integrated into the main on-land Deccan stratigraphy. Results of these studies will be compared with other Phanerozoic CFB events, some of which are and, importantly, some of which are not associated with mass extinction.

por.por_cntn:
The mass extinction at the end of the Cretaceous Period 66 million years ago is widely attributed to the asteroid impact in Mexico that formed the Chicxulub crater. At around the same time, however, massive outpouring of basaltic magmas occurred in what is now India, forming the Deccan traps. The central goal of this project was to determine whether the impact may have modulated the eruption tempo of Deccan volcanism and to quantify the role of the eruptions on environmental change and the extinction. To do so required determining the source of magmas, the eruption chronology and volumes, and the relationship to documented changes in Earth systems. Addressing this goal also required developing new fundamental understanding of how impacts and volcanism are connected, and the processes that lead to volcanic eruptions.

 

Using a collection of new samples, field mapping, and high-precision argon geochronology, we found that more than 90% of Deccan lavas erupted within a short one-million-year period of time, and 75% of lavas were emplaced shortly after the end of the Cretaceous. This chronology implies that Deccan volcanism did not dominate Late Cretaceous climate change. To obtain a high-resolution history of the tempo of eruption, geochemical proxies were used to determine eruption durations and rates. Mercury measurements suggest that individual eruptions lasted for centuries and that tens to hundreds of cubic kilometers of magma erupted each year. These geochemical measurements were complemented with the first global compilation of pahoehoe lava-lobe thickness from continental flood basalt provinces and new measurements of Deccan lava flows. Those field studies also connected the erupted lava flows to the locations and orientations of their feeder dikes. While the bulk of erupted  Deccan magma formed lava flows, lava fountains and explosive eruptions from magma-water interactions may have had a disproportionately large effect on marine chemistry and productivity.

 

Interpreting geochronology and field data required advancing our understanding of fundamental volcanological processes. Assessing the eruption rate and eruption volumes from deposits requires an interpretation of measured lava flow thicknesses. We showed that heat transfer between successively emplaced lava flow can make the final deposit appear to comprise thicker flows, leading to a systematic bias in eruption volumes. We developed a new thermal-mechanical-poroelastic model for how magma is stored within the crust and the conditions under which that magma can erupt. The model was used to describe a parameter space in which different properties of the crust and processes within the subsurface dominate different regimes of eruption and magma evolution. With a quantitative understanding of how magma reservoirs evolve combined with eruption chronologies, we showed that continental flood basalts were likely fed by multiple interconnected small-to-medium sized magma reservoirs, consistent with the emerging paradigm of trans-crustal magma systems. Using laboratory experiments we identified how conduit and dike geometries promote long-lived eruptions. The 2018 Kilauea eruption provided an opportunity to identify and explain a new mechanism for generating ash in lava fountains.

 

We used an up-to-date data set of volcanic eruptions and earthquakes to determine the conditions under which dynamic strains from earthquakes (and impacts) trigger volcanic eruptions. We found that large, regional earthquakes increase the probability of eruptions by a few tens of percent over a period of a couple years. Modeling the propagation of seismic waves from the Chicxulub impact and the amplification of deformation with magma bodies and partially molten regions in the upper mantle, enabled us to determine the effects of the impact on the magmatic system feeding Deccan eruptions. We also performed laboratory experiments to study how deformation affects the mobility of crystal-rich magmas and affects crystallization kinetics. We found that deformation enhances nucleation and crystal growth rates.

 

Students and postdocs supported by this project received multidisciplinary training. They engaged in modeling, analytical laboratory measurements, data analysis, and fieldwork. They have moved on the research positions in government agencies,  and to faculty positions at universities. Scientific results were published in research papers, dissertations, and presented at scientific conferences. Results were communicated beyond the scientific community via the University of California Museum of Paleontology’s website deccan.berkeley.edu through both scientific resources and K-12 resources.
